The '''Barrow-downs''' or '''''Tyrn Gorthad''''' were a series of treeless hills east of [[the Shire]], behind the [[Old Forest]], and south-west of the village of [[Bree]].<ref>{{UT|Map}}</ref> They were called the Barrow-downs, because many of the hills were crowned with [[barrows]] (burial mounds). Standing stones stood on some of the green mounds. The Barrow-downs were a treeless country that was covered with grass and turf.<ref name=Barrow>{{FR|Barrow}}, pp. 136-142</ref>

==History==
In the late [[First Age]] the ancestors of the [[Edain]] built many of the barrows in the Barrow-downs before they migrated west to [[Beleriand]].<ref name=ArgelebII>{{App|Eriador}}, ''The North-kindom and the Dúnedain'', entry for King Argeleb II, p. 1041</ref>

In the [[Second Age]] many Men that were descended from the ancestors of the Edain, primarily from the [[House of Beor|Folk of Beor]] and partly from the [[House of Hador|Folk of Hador]] lived near [[Lake Evendim]], in the [[North Downs]], in the [[Weather Hills]] and in the land between.<ref>{{PM|Atani}}</ref> It is not known if they lived as far south as the Barrow-downs at that time. During the [[Dark Years]] Men who were related to the [[Dunlendings]] had migrated from the valleys of the [[White Mountains]] to the empty lands as far north as the Barrow-downs.<ref>{{App|Men}}, p. 1130</ref>

When [[Elendil]] escaped to [[Middle-earth]] from the [[Downfall of Númenor]] and established the [[Realms in Exile]] in {{SA|3320}}<ref>{{App|SA}}, entry for the year 3320, p. 1084</ref> the Barrow-downs became a part of the kingdom of [[Arnor]].<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, p. 1039</ref> The Barrow-downs were revered by the [[Dúnedain]] of Arnor, because many of the barrows had been built by their forefathers in the First Age, and they buried their lords and Kings there.<ref name=ArgelebII/>

After the division of the kingdom of Arnor into the kingdoms of [[Arthedain]], [[Rhudaur]] and [[Cardolan]] in {{TA|861}}<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 861, p. 1085</ref> the Barrow-downs became a part of the kingdom of [[Cardolan]].<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, ''The North-kingdom and the Dúnedain'', entry for the time after King Eärendur, p. 1039</ref>

In {{TA|1409}},<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1409, p. 1086</ref> a large army from the kingdom of [[Angmar]] invaded the kingdom of Cardolan. The Dúnedain of Cardolan were defeated and Cardolan was ravaged, but a part of the Dúnedain of Cardolan defended the Barrow-downs or fled into the safety of the [[Old Forest]]. The forces of Angmar were eventually defeated by [[Elves]] from [[Lindon]], [[Rivendell]] and [[Lothlórien]] and subdued for a while.<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, ''The North-kingdom and the Dúnedain'', entry for King Arveleg I, p. 1040</ref>

Around {{TA|1636}}<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1636, p. 1086</ref> the [[Great Plague]] spread to Cardolan from the South-west and most of the population of Cardolan died. The [[Witch-king]] sent<ref name=Other>{{UT|Other}}</ref> [[Barrow-wights|evil spirits]] from Angmar and Rhudaur to the Barrow-downs, which inhabited the deserted barrows.<ref name=ArgelebII/> It is possible that the terror of the Barrow-wights prevented any attempt to resettle the Barrow-downs.<ref name=Araval>{{PM|Elendil}}, manuscript C, The Northern Line of Arnor: the Isildurioni, 23. Araval</ref>

Around September 24 {{TA|3018}} the [[Nazgûl|Black Riders]] entered Cardolan.<ref name=RC>{{HM|RC}}, "Fog on the Barrow-downs", p. 145</ref> Their chief, the [[Witch-king]], moved to [[Andrath]], visited the Barrow-downs, roused the Barrow-wights to be on the watch<ref name=Other/> in order to trap the [[Ring]]-bearer and left on September 27.<ref name=RC/>

On [[28 September]] {{TA|3018}}<ref>{{App|Great}}, entry for the year 3018, September 28, p. 1091</ref> [[Frodo]], [[Sam]], [[Pippin]] and [[Merry]] were trapped in the downs by a [[Barrow-wights|wight]], probably in the same mound which contained the grave of the [[last prince of Cardolan]]<ref name=ArgelebII/> (it is likely that Merry saw his last memories in his dreams, because he mentioned the "men of [[Carn Dûm]]").<ref name=RC/> They were rescued by [[Tom Bombadil]], who amassed the barrow’s mighty hoard and gave them four special [[Daggers of Westernesse|swords]]. Tom took a brooch set with blue stones for [[Goldberry]] and said that it was long ago worn by a fair woman on her shoulder and that he and Goldberry would not forget her.<ref name=Barrow/> It is possible that the brooch had belonged to the wife of or a woman from the family of the [[last prince of Cardolan]], because it was in the barrow that contained his grave.<ref name="RS|Wight">{{RS|Wight}}, p. 128</ref>

==Etymology==
A "barrow" (or "berrow"; from English beorg, berg, 'hill, mound') not to be confused with the wheeled vehicle, is a tumulus or other prehistoric grave-mound.<ref name="Nomen">{{HM|N}}, entry , '''Barrow-downs''', p. 766</ref>

In topography, a "down" is a low-lying hill, from the [[Old English|Anglo-Saxon]] ''dún'' meaning "hill".<ref name="ASD">Joseph Bosworth and T. Northcote Toller, "[http://bosworth.ff.cuni.cz/008106 DÚN]" at ''An Anglo-Saxon Dictionary'' (accessed 12 October 2010)</ref> In the [[wikipedia:United Kingdom|United Kingdom]], a [[wikipedia:Downland|down]] is a gently-rolling chalk hill in Southern [[wikipedia:England|England]] (seen especially in the [[wikipedia:North Downs|North]] and [[wikipedia:South Downs|South Downs]]).<ref name="OD">[http://oxforddictionaries.com/ Oxford Dictionaries], "[http://oxforddictionaries.com/view/entry/m_en_gb0241750?rskey=YT9je8&result=4#m_en_gb0241750 down]" (accessed 12 October 2010)</ref>

The name therefore would represent an earlier [[Old English]] form ''Beorga Dune'' "downs of barrows".<ref name=etym>{{webcite|author=[[David Salo]]|articleurl=https://tolkienlistsearch.herokuapp.com/message/5e9c35b63ee6a6c41e9862d6|articlename=Hobbitish Place-names (1.21)|dated=23 November 1998|website=[[Elfling]]|accessed=2022-09-23}}</ref>

'''''Tyrn Gorthad''''' was the [[Sindarin]] name of the Barrow-downs. ''Tyrn Gorthad'' is a compound of the plural<ref>{{webcite|author=Paul Strack|articleurl=https://www.eldamo.org/content/words/word-344758281.html|articlename=S. ''Tyrn Gorthad'' loc.|website=Eldamo|accessed=05 March 2022}}</ref> ''tyrn'' of ''[[torn]]'' ("burial mound") and ''[[gorthad]]'' ("wraith, spirit of dead").<ref>{{PE|17}}, p. 116</ref> In one manuscript, the name ''Tyrn Goerthaid'' was used by [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]].<ref>{{PM|Elendil}}, manuscript C with corrections and expansions, The Northern Line of Arnor: the Isildurioni 20. Argeleb II, p. 194</ref> ''Goerthaid'' seems to be the [[Sindarin#Plural|plural]] of ''gorthad'' with [[affection|affected]] vowels.

==Other versions of the legendarium== 
In the earlier versions of the story, the barrows were said to belong to the men who “fought against the evil foes” when “the world was still young”. The cairn where the Hobbits were trapped was said to be the barrow of a prince of this kingdom who died during the war (the identification of the buried prince with the [[Last prince of Cardolan|last prince]] and the occurrence of Cardolan, Angmar and Carn Dûm are only in subsequent versions).<ref>{{RS|Wight}}, pp. 127-128</ref><ref>{{TI|Bree}}, p. 37</ref> 

Also, in the earlier versions of Tom Bombadil’s statement regarding the blue-jewelled brooch he took for Goldberry, and the mysterious lady that once wore it, he mentioned that “they shall not forget” the kings, the warriors, the children and the fair maidens of the past, suggesting they were interred there and Bombadil had met them long ago.<ref name="RS|Wight"/>

In an earlier version of what would later become Appendix A King Araval of Arthedain tried to resettle Cardolan, but the Barrow-wights terrified anybody who attempted to live near the Barrow-downs.<ref name=Araval/>

==Portrayal in adaptations==
[[File:The Lord of the Rings Online - Barrow-downs.jpg|thumb|Barrow-downs in ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'']]
'''2002: [[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (video game)|''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' (video game)]]:'''
:Hobbits' passage through the Barrow-downs is represented by a respective level.

'''2006: ''[[The Battle for Middle-earth II: The Rise of the Witch-king]]'':'''
:In his campaign against the former kingdom of Arnor the Witch-king dispatches his men led by [[Hwaldar]] to claim the royal barrows to enrage Cardolan and lure out their forces to destroy their army and lay Cardolan bare for his attacks, while unintentionally slaying a prince of Cardolan. Later he attacked the Barrow-downs a second time to desecrate the barrows to create a plague to weaken the rest of Arnor and to demoralize the Dúnedain of Cardolan by using the barrows as the plague's ground zero. In the resulting battle [[Karsh|Carthaen]], a general of Cardolan, was slain and Cardolan's sent army was destroyed.

'''2007: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'':'''
:The Barrow-downs, part of the [[Bree-land]] region, are divided into North and South Barrows, depicted as a series of mounds crowned with megaliths. The region is inhabited by wights, recently stirred by the passage of the [[Nazgûl]]. The largest and oldest barrow is called "[[Othrongroth]]".

:A further southern part of the downs, specifically called Tyrn Gorthad, is part of the [[Cardolan]] region. It contains the ruins of "Dol Ernil", the capital of the ruling Princes of Cardolan after Cardolan's line of kings failed. Like the Barrows in Bree-land, it is also haunted by the restless Dead.

'''2011: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: War in the North]]'':'''
<!--Add image-->
:After [[Halbarad]] sends [[Eradan (video game character)|Eradan]], [[Andriel]] and [[Farin (video game character)|Farin]] to warn [[Aragorn]] in Bree, the three heroes travel through the Barrow-downs as a shortcut.<ref>[http://www.oxmonline.com/ Official Xbox Magazine Online], [http://www.oxmonline.com/article/previews/g-l/lord-rings-war-north The Lord of the Rings: War in the North], dated [[28 April]], [[2011]] (accessed at [[7 July]], [[2011]])</ref> On their way, they have to save two Dúnedain Rangers named Luin and Kilaran. Throughout the whole level, fog hangs above the ground.<ref>[http://www.warinthenorth.com The Lord of the Rings: War in the North's Official Site], [http://www.warinthenorth.com/index.php/media/videos Videos], The Lord of the Rings: War in the North - Dev video: Art Direction Process, dated [[11 May]], [[2011]] (accessed [[14 September]], [[2011]])</ref> Upon reaching Rivendell, the three heroes can talk to Frodo about their escapades in the Barrow-downs. 

'''2012-14: [[The Hobbit (film series)|''The Hobbit'' (film series)]]:'''
:At one point, the script included the Barrow-downs. [[John Howe]] and others visited "an extraordinary place on a farm in the North Island, which would have been so wonderfully perfect", described by Howe as "incredibly exciting, and the scenery was so terrifically strange it would have been hard to believe it was natural". The scene was later written out of the script.<ref>{{webcite|author=Erie Rizzi Neves|articleurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20201020083519/https://tolkieniana.net/wp/intervista-a-john-howe/2/|articlename=An Interview with John Howe|dated=14 October, 2020|website=Tolkieniana|accessed=1 December, 2025}}</ref>
